info.game_comments: April Fool's show with cameo appearances by Will Ferrell (as his Alex Trebek character from "Saturday Night Live"), Neil Patrick Harris, Jeff Probst, and Pat Sajak.

(1, 1).clue: This New Yorker who fought at the battle of Gettysburg was once considered the inventor of baseball

(2, 1).clue: Divorcee Jane, having an affair with her ex, Jake, played by Alec Baldwin

(3, 1).clue: This candy melts in your mouth, not in your hand & puts money into Kyle Busch's No. 18

(5, 1).clue: London's Daily Mail said a mistranslation caused an entrant in one of these to run 26 days not 26 miles

(6, 1).clue: This 2-word term for 8 specific colleges in the east refers to the vegetation covering their older buildings

(1, 2).clue: This First Lady was born Thelma Catherine Ryan on March 16, 1912 in Nevada

(3, 2).clue: What can brown do for David Ragan, No. 6? Be this delivery company & sponsor, that's what

(4, 2).clue: Sun Yat-Sen, at the corner of Grant & California

(5, 2).clue: In 2004 NPR reported that the post office was allowing people to take these 5-digit numbers with them when they moved

(6, 2).clue: The name of this mass of ice comes from the Old French for "ice"

(1, 3).clue: From 1935 to 1937 she worked at Purdue University as a career counselor & as an advisor in aeronautics

(3, 3).clue: When it comes to sponsorships, No. 43, Reed Sorenson, asks for supersize from this fast food chain

(4, 3).clue: Douglas MacArthur, near the Quezon bridge

(5, 3).clue: An Aussie news show reported in 1975 that the country was converting to this "time" with 100 minutes in an hour

(6, 3).clue: This word for a long-noosed rope used to catch cattle & horses is from the Spanish la reata, "the rope"

(1, 4).clue: At his death in 1915, this educator was buried on the campus of his Tuskegee institute

(3, 4).clue: This energy drink gives Scott Speed's No. 82 wings (& dollars)

(4, 4).clue: A work symbolizing freedom & unity by Bassem Al-Dawiri (replacing a guy who got toppled)

(5, 4).clue: The Irish Times said in 1995 that this Russian leader's embalmed body would go from Red Square to Euro Disney

(6, 4).clue: A 15th century sailor is said to have given this snake its name, from a Portuguese phrase meaning "hooded snake"

(1, 5).clue: He wrote a controversial report on urban poverty before being a democratic senator from New York, 1977-2001

(3, 5).clue: This home improvement store tells Jimmie Johnson's 48 crew, "let's build something together"

(4, 5).clue: 18th-century hero Colonel William Prescott seen herein a state capital

(5, 5).clue: A 1972 veterinary record article said "Brunus edwardii", this creature, was in 63.8% of households

(6, 5).clue: The first written use of the phrase "stuffed shirt", meaning a pompous bore, occurred in her 1913 novel "O Pioneers!"

(1, 1).clue: Ayn Rand's original title for this 1957 novel was "The Strike"

(2, 1).clue: A book on the science of champagne says lipstick can ruin the fun: fats in it make these stretch & break

(3, 1).clue: This 1928 Ravel work was written on commission from ballet dancer Ida Rubinstein

(4, 1).clue: If you are in tune with someone, you are said to be on the same this, a distance in physics

(5, 1).clue: When ailing, Hindus bathe in this, India's most sacred river; and once dead, their ashesare scattered therein

(1, 2).clue: Irving Stone's "Love is Eternal" told the story of this 19th century presidential couple, the good & the bad

(2, 2).clue: A 1980s process to make huge bottles safely allowed Rosalynn Carter to do this with a 7-gal. "sovereign" on Jan. 15, 1988
(2, 2).correct response: christen a ship (\'break it across a ship\' accepted)

(3, 2).clue: This Sibelius work was performed using the title "Impromptu" while his country was under Russian rule

(4, 2).clue: Literally referring to something blown down, it's used to mean "an unexpected gain"

(5, 2).clue: Because the Jordan is at a tenth of its normal flow, the briny waters of this sea have dropped 130 feet since 1980

(1, 3).clue: Yep, in a 1958 novel, James Bond found himself up against this sinister sadist in the Caribbean

(2, 3).clue: Laurent-Perrier ultra brut is made without dosage, the usual addition of mostly this common substance

(3, 3).clue: In 1858, after his death, his "Wedding March" became a tradition after its use in a royal wedding

(4, 3).clue: As Juliet knows, this 9-letter word means "why?"

(5, 3).clue: Low snowpacks & multiyear drought have reduced Lake Shasta, in this California range, to a remnant of its former self

(1, 4).clue: This sizzling bestseller from Grace Metalious spawned a movie & a prime time soap

(2, 4).clue: Though champagne is white, one of the most important grapes used to make it is this one whose name in part means "black"

(4, 4).clue: This word for a phantom or a ghost is of Scottish origin
